conversation.content: [hushed] I found the trades buried in subsidiary accounts, millions moving three days before every major announcement we've made this quarter. This could kill our IPO next month.
[calmly] Show me the pattern you're seeing. In my experience, these things are either very simple or very sophisticated, rarely anything in between.
[anxiously] It's our CFO's nephew, twenty-three years old, using his girlfriend's father's brokerage account. The kid made four million in six weeks. [exhales] The SEC will tear us apart.
Four million is enough to be noticed but not enough to run. He's still playing with house money, which means he thinks he's untouchable. [thoughtfully]
[desperate] We go public in thirty-two days. If this surfaces, every institutional investor will pull out, and eight years of building this company goes straight to hell.
The girlfriend's father, does he know his account's been compromised? Because that changes our approach considerably.
He's in assisted living with dementia. The kid has power of attorney. [bitterly] It's almost elegant how he set it up.
[impressed] Clever boy.
[sharply] Clever? He's destroying everything we've built! Our employees have stock options that'll be worthless if this gets out.
[measured] Three options here. We can make him disappear financially, make the trades disappear digitally, or make the whole thing look like something else entirely. Each has a different price point.
[quietly] I've never done anything like this before. My whole career has been about transparency, proper disclosures, keeping everything above board. [sighs]
Above board is a luxury for companies that don't have nephews with gambling problems and access to material information. You called me, which means you've already decided. [pause]
[resigned] The third option, making it look like something else. What would that involve exactly?
We create a paper trail showing the kid was being fed false information by a competitor trying to manipulate your stock. He becomes a victim, not a perpetrator.
[skeptical] And people will believe that? The timing on these trades is perfect, every single one of them.
[confidently] People believe what makes sense with the evidence presented. I'll need access to your competitor's communication systems for about six hours. Can you get me that?
[nervously] Our CEO golfs with their CEO every Sunday. I could probably get into their guest network during the next round. [swallows hard] Jesus, listen to what I'm saying.
Two hundred thousand. [flatly]
[stunned] That's it? I mean, that's a lot, but I expected... I don't know what I expected actually.
[wryly] I'm not fixing a presidential election here. Just some creative accounting and digital archaeology. Half now, half when your IPO closes successfully. [stands]
